_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION & EMERGENCY RESPONSE
The Carpenter Co., both Corporate and Lakeland Division, operate the facility with attention and a serious commitment to the implementation of safe work procedures and the protection of the environment.  The Lakeland Division of Carpenter Co. utilizes an Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP) to manage the emergency response activities at the facility.  The implementation of the ICP at the facility is directly related to the degree of training given to the Carpenter Co. employees in regard to chemical releases and emergencies, fire evacuation and preparation for response to the effect of natural disasters.  The Lakeland Division's attention to Accidental Release Prevention is evidenced by the facility's having only one significant release of toluene diisocyanate during the previous five years.  This release was completely contained within the building and rersulted in no off-site impact.

2.  FACILITY DESCRIPTION & REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
The Carpenter Co., Lakeland Division, is located at 5150 Frontage Road South in Lakeland, Florida.  The area around the facility is comprised of other industrial plants. The Carpenter Co., Lakeland Division, employees approximately 125 full-time employees.  The facility manufactures polyurethane foam products for use in carpet cushioning, bedding and furniture applications.  The polyurethane foam manufacturing process utilizes toluene diisocyanate (TDI) [unspecified isomers], CAS# 2647-62-5, in the respective process.  The Carpenter Co., Lakeland facility has a total TDI storage capacity of approximately 556,528 pounds.  The facility maintains one railcar with approximately 185,000 pounds of TDI, one internal TDI storage tank with a capacity of 312,516 pounds, one internal TDI prepolymer mixing tank with a capacity of 91,550 pounds, and one TDI prepolymer day tank with a capacity of 31,518 pounds.  All process tanks are located inside the building with the railcar located outsi

; Preventive Maintenance Plan; RMP Compliance Audits; and TDI Incident Investigation.

6.  FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
Over the previous five year the Carpenter Co., Lakeland Division, has had only one significant incident involving toluene diisocyanate (unspecified isomers).  This incident involved the failure of a prepolymer tank that resulted in the release of prepolymer (42% TDI) inside the building.  The release did not impact people or the environment beyond the property line.

7.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The Carpenter Co., Lakeland Division, utilizes an Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP) to outline the emergency response activities for each class of incident that may occur at the facility.  The facility has made all required notifications to the Polk County LEPC regarding the types of materials stored at the facility and their volumes.  Carpenter Co. has an Emergency Response Service Agreement with American Complinace Technologies to provide remediation services in the event a TDI release should occur.  Carpenter Co. maintains a trained HazMat response team capable of actively controlling a release of TDI.  All Carpenter Co. operations and support personnel have received training in TDI hazard recognition and awareness as well as a thorough review of MSDS sheets.  Tha facility conducts emergency response drills on a regular basis.

8.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The Carpenter Co., Lakeland Division, operates with an attention to employee awareness and emphasizes ingoing training of all personnel.  Additional employees will recieve 24-hour HazMat responder training.  A TDI unloading checklist will be implemented to ensure equipment is in satisfactory condition prior to use.

de at the railcar unloading station.  The unloading station has stationary drip pans installed to minimize incidental releases.

3.  WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO
The Carpenter Co., Lakeland Division, utilized the modified Gaussian plume model presented in the EPA Off-Site Consequence Analysis (OCA) for the determination of off-site impact.  The Worst-Case  Scenario consists of the catastrophic loss of one railcar of TDI, approximately 185,000 pounds at a temperature of 49.0C onto an uncontained area.  The TDI pool area is calculated to be approximately 76,000 square feet.  The resulting toxic endpoint is calculated to to be 1261 feet or 0.24 miles.  Within the area delineated by the endpoint distance there are no residential receptors, however 7 industrial businesses would be impacted.

4.  ALTERNATIVE CASE RELEASE SCENARIO
The alternative release scenario is based on the failure of a transfer hose that results in the loss of its contents.  The volume of TDI present in the hose is calculated to be 100 pounds of liquid which would be lost on to the ballast rock present at the railcar unloading dock.  The pool area is resulting from this spill would equal 40 square feet with an estimated endpoint distance of 41 feet or <0.01 miles.  Based on the calculated endpoint distance a release of this magnitude would not impact any off-site residental or industrial receptors.

5.  GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM & CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The Carpenter Co. has implemented the RMP Program Level 2 Prevention Program, as described in the RMP regulations, at this facility which includes the following elements: TDI Safety Information, Health Guidelines, & MSDS Sheets; Hazard Review utilizing What-if Checklists; Standard Operating Procedures - TDI Unloading Procedure, Transfer Pump Operating & Shutdown Procedures, Recirculation Pump Operating & Shutdown Procedures, Metering Pump Operating & Shutdown Procedures, Pourline Operating Procedures; Employee Training
